Bangladesh ICT has made ‘mockery of international law’ – Defence Team


The International Defence Team of Abdul Quader Mollah has condemned ‘retrospective sentencing’ of Jammat-e-Islami leader to death by Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. The team also called for internationally supervised inquiry into the conduct of the trial, a press statement revealed.
Two foreign legal counsel of the defence found, “Retrospective amendment makes ‘a mockery of international law”.
The defence accused the government of staging a ‘political show trial’ aimed at helping the ruling party secure power in upcoming elections.
They also criticized the proceeding of sentencing the Jamaat leader  expressing dismay that  law was changed to allow retrospective sentencing ‘after Prime Minister  Sheikh Hasina’s intervention in Parliament’.
Toby Cadman and  John Cammegh, the foreign legal counsels of the defence,  expressed views  in the statement following the sentencing of Abdul Quader Mollah by the Appellate Division.
They also call to halt trials and demanded an international inquiry.
"It is deeply regrettable that the Supreme Court has failed to remedy the very serious defects in the trial process and has upheld a law that we consider to be in breach of fundamental rights,” added Cadman.
"Coupled with the Government’s consistent pressure to ignore due process and deliver speedy convictions and prompt executions, the process has become a mockery of international law and undermines all major international instruments that protect fundamental human rights principles”, commented John Cammegh.
